instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00244: What is 820-00244? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.820-00045: What is 820-00045? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - bad CPU/Boots to file with ?
threads.message:
Hi

I have <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> MacBook Board, it originally had burned/discolored <CHIP>U7210</CHIP>/L7210.

I replaced <CHIP>U7210</CHIP> and L7210 and it still would not boot.

I figured damaged/bad CPU, so I replaced CPU on my BGA rework station.

Now the MacBook boots normally but it is not detecting internal SSD (Boots to folder with ?), it also boots fine off bootable OS via USB.

This may have been a problem before I swapped CPU, but I am not sure, any ideas to troubleshoot the undetected SSD would be great.

I did measure SSD line voltage:
1v8 cold - 2.8v
1v2 cold - 1.3v
1v8 hot - 1.8v
1v2 hot - 1.2v
0v9 core - .9v
0v9 Fixed - .9v

Thanks

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - bad CPU/Boots to file with ?
threads.message:
"1v8 cold - 2.8v"
It is strange, are you sure?

Failing SSD is classic issue on these boards, as CPU too.
Some people on Internet claim they solved this reballing SSD controller.
However, do not expect a miracle.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - bad CPU/Boots to file with ?
threads.message:
sorry 2.8v was typo! 1.8v is correct.

I assume controller is <CHIP>U8600</CHIP>?

Thank you

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - bad CPU/Boots to file with ?
threads.message: If you already replaced CPU, <CHIP>U8600</CHIP> should give you less problems to reball.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - bad CPU/Boots to file with ?
threads.message:
Sorry to resurrect this thread.

I have done [B]3x[/B] CPU swaps to <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>.

Each one of these boards has initially had a burned up <CHIP>U7210</CHIP> and L7210 which killed the CPU, the boards all have no power originally. I then changed CPU to new CPU and [B]all 3 of the boards turned on.[/B] The problem is that [B]all 3 of the boards now boot to file with ? (No SSD detected).[/B]

Is there something I am missing here? I have done many CPU swaps on <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> and I never have issue with file with ? afterwards.

Is there anything anyone can think of as to why I keep getting missing SSD on <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> after successful CPU swap?

[B]It feels like I must be doing something wrong[/B], but I can't figure it out based on schematic or board view.

Any ideas would be greatly appreciated!

Thanks!!
